Ultimatly, I doubt that we will ever run out of oil. There are 2 scenarios that I think are probable when it comes to the end of the oil age. First, we may see an orderly transition from oil to alternative forms of energy. This would have to be coupled with a SERIOUS change in the lifestyles of most of the world, and would almost certianly include a decrease in the human population of the planet, since even if you discount energy we are extremely reliant on hydrocarbons from oil and those alternative forms of energy do not yield cheap hydrocarbons.
 
 The other scenario is a disorderly one. In this scenario, supply and demand lines cross and rather than a peaceful, orderly change, we see massive die offs, war, and famine. Ultimatly the human race implodes to the point that the massive infrastructure needed to pump, transport, and refine oil is no longer available, so the oil stops flowing.
 
 Ultimatly, given the data we have today, the second scenario seems FAR more likely. We do not currently have alternative energy sources that can come anywhere close to competing with oil. While we certainly have good, cheap ways to produce electricity, electricity is a pretty poor transportation fuel, and it does not do anything as far as providing us with hydrocarbons. The alternative energy sources we do have right now for transportation fuels all depend on cheap hydrocarbon input to be cost effective (ethanol, etc...). 
 
 Ultimatly, most of the alternatives we DO have on the horizon are decades away from full implementation at any kind of scale that may even be able to replace a fraction of the oil we use. At the same time, all real indicators point to a peak in oil production and a susequent crossing of the supply and demand lines long before we have the chance to implement any of those programs on any really meaningful scale. The hirsh report claims that it would take a minimum of 20 years of crash programs in order to mitigate the effects of a peak in our oil supply. There are no such programs currently planned or funded.
 
 Ultimatly the arrival of a peak in oil supplies will mean that we will have to resign ourselves to a more sustainable human population for the planet earth. Estimates of what that might be range from a pretty depressing 500 million (probably low) to a nearly chearful 3 billion (probbaly a little high). With our current population of 6 billion, even the upper range estimates are pretty damn depressing.

 Shell took reserve write downs on several of their fields - IMHO, this is only evidence that the system is working, it's nothing new or shocking. The company I used to work for would take write downs on some of its fields every year. It has to do with the reserve auditors adjusting the total reserves of the field due to additional drilling and well production performance within the field.
 
 "Everyone does it" is a typical answer anytime you get caught with your hand in the cookie jar. In a sense, they're right. It's every oil companies goal to get the maximum amount of reserves possible accounted for and recognized. They do everything they can to maximize that number, it's where their value lies. That's why the entire system of the independent reserve audit system and government regulations were put in place - as a system of checks and balances to maintain veracity of the reserve reports and to make sure that all companies were operating under the same rules.
 
 Most middle eastern and other OPEC nations present "official reserves reports", but they refuse access to independent reserve auditors that would verify those reports - for obvious reasons.
